courseWork.title: AP Computer Science Exam Study Guide
courseWork.description:
All,

Apologies for the last-minute assignment posting. Students will submit an exam study guide covering all topics we've discussed this year.
The study guide should aim to cover every topic we've explored or discussed on labs, quizzes, the midterm, and AP Classroom.
Each review topic should also include a code example where relevant in the respective course language (Java / Python).
Students may collaborate, but all students must submit a review guide individually.
The document can be submitted as a Google Doc, PDF, or README.md file.
We will use our time in class today to start drafting the study guide.

Best of luck on the exam,

Mr. Mazey
courseWork.descriptionHtml:
All,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
Study Materials for Spring Break

All,

I have posted OPTIONAL content on AP Classroom for anyone looking to practice over Spring Break. I strongly suggest you review these materials if you intend to pass in May. We will only have roughly 4 days of review when we return from Spring Break before the actual exam. Coming prepared with specific questions will greatly enhance the value of the review.

Practice Test 3 and every AP Unit Check-In Quiz have been provided to you this morning. I advise you to watch the videos on AP Classroom for the topics you struggle with the most, take the check-in quiz, and then complete PT3 towards the end of the break if you want to maximize all materials.

I am giving a large presentation on April 23rd -- while my availability via email will be inconsistent, I still encourage you to email me with any questions you may have.

Best of luck!

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
Reminder on PT2

All,

Several students have yet to submit Practice Test 2. Please make time to do so today if you have not already completed PT2. The exam will close at 11.45pm EST. While PT2 won't be "graded," you will be receiving points in PowerSchool for submitting it.

The results from PT2 will motivate our final review in the week leading up to the actual AP exam after we return from Spring Break. Please put your best effort into both sections.

Thank you,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
Practice Test 2 & Science Symposium

All,

We will be hosting Practice Test 2 (PT2) on Wednesday, April 9th after school. Being that this exam is taking place outside normal school hours, participation is optional; however, ALL STUDENTS must complete PT2 no later than Sunday, April 13th @ 11.59pm. Students will receive points in PowerSchool for completing PT2 -- failure to submit the exam will result in a 0 for the assignment.

Exam results from PT2 will motivate our final review leading up to the actual AP exam. A strong performance on PT2 is essential for any student planning to pass AP CS A in May. I suggest you spend some time reviewing this weekend to get the most out of PT2 and our subsequent review.

Additionally, we will be participating in Science Symposium the following day on Thursday, April 10th. Students may choose to demonstrate any project they have worked on this year. Students who participate in Science Symposium will be awarded extra credit towards their Q4 grade.

This coming weekend is among the final weekends you have to prepare for the exam in May. Please use your time wisely and email me if you have any questions.

Good luck,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
Oops, All Arrays!

Good morning,

I am under the weather today and will not be attending class. Please use our time today to complete the Oops, All Arrays! quiz assigned in AP Classroom. While the quiz will not be added to PowerSchool, your performance on this quiz is a strong indicator of how you will perform on the actual AP exam, so please do your best.

We will be reviewing Huffman implementations and the quiz results when I return tomorrow.

Thank you,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
👩‍🔬Lab 6: Huffman Encoding👩‍🔬

In this lab students will implement the Huffman Encoding algorithm. Please begin the lab by forking and cloning our class repository: https://github.com/bmazey/st-saviour-huffman

Key Concepts
Common data structures in Java (HashMap, PriorityQueue).
Trees
Object-Oriented Programming
Iteration
Recursion
Students are tasked to implement the missing methods provided in the course repository.

Grading Criteria
Node class implementation (15 points)
Leaf class implementation (15 points)
Huffman populateFrequenciesMap() method (10 points)
Huffman encode() method (10 points)
Huffman generateCodes() method (10 points)
Huffman getEncodedText() method (10 points)
Huffman decode() method (10 points)
Style & documentation (20 points)
Students may add three unique test cases in the provided testing directory for +10 bonus points. More information on the Huffman algorithm can be found using the link below.

DUE DATE: Monday, March 24th @ 11.59pm EST

announcement.text:
Lab 5: Bazaar of Istanbul

In this lab students will explore the use of multidimensional arrays in Java. Each student must weave a set of Turkish rugs using the emojis of their choice. The five required rug patterns are as follows:

    Solid (20 points)
    Horizontal (20 points)
    Vertical (20 points)
    Diagonal (20 points)
    Plaid (20 points)
All rugs should be 11x11 String arrays. Students may also submit an argyle rug pattern for an additional +10 points. Please see the attached screenshots for pattern references.

Students are responsible for creating their own GitHub repository.

I strongly suggest each student start by implementing a method to print a formatted 2D String array (ex: weave() method) and a separate method to generate each rug pattern (ex: solid() method). 

Students must submit a link to their GitHub repository and screenshots of each generated rug pattern to receive full credit.

Lab 5 Due Date: Friday, February 14th @ 11.59pm

link.title: Protected Keyword in Java with Examples - GeeksforGeeks
Class Diagram | Unified Modeling Language (UML) - GeeksforGeeks

announcement.text:
Lab 4: 👩‍🎤📈 OOPs! I Did It Again 👩‍🎤📈

In this lab exercise students will explore Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts in Java by creating their own inheritance structure.

Key Concepts
Inheritance (extends, implements)
Polymorphism (instanceof)
Key word abstract
Key word super
Access modifiers (public, private), setter() / getter() design pattern.
ArrayList<T>
This lab is broken down into three parts -- students must complete all three sections to receive full credit. Students may work in groups, but all work will be submitted and graded individually. Students may begin the lab by forking & cloning the following repository: https://github.com/bmazey/st-saviour-oop-java

Part 1: Unified Model Language (UML) Diagram (10 points)
Before writing code, students must first create a UML diagram which describes the relationship between their intended classes. The designed structure must contain at least four (4) classes: one abstract grandparent class, one parent class, and two children classes. The structure must also define at least one interface and a class which implements the interface. The UML diagram may be submitted digitally or drawn on paper.

More information on UML class diagrams can be found here: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/unified-modeling-language-uml-class-diagrams/

LAB 4 PART 1 DUE DATE: Friday, December 13th 2024 (submitted in class, or on Google Classroom)

Part 2: Java Implementation (60 points)
After receiving approval on the diagram submitted in Part 1 students may begin the implementation of the designed structure. The structure must address the following criteria for full credit (10 points each):
Contains at least four (4) classes, with at least one class being abstract.
Demonstrates working knowledge of key word extends.
Contains at least one (1) interface, and a class which implements the interface.
Demonstrates working knowledge of key word super.
Demonstrates knowledge of access modifiers (public, private) using setter() / getter() methods.
May or may not contain an example of ArrayList<T>.
Part 3: Tests & Validation (30 points)
Your lab submission should include tests which demonstrate polymorphic types and a functional inheritance hierarchy. The tests must address the following criteria for full credit (10 points each):
Asserts polymorphic types using instanceof operator.
Confirms presence of inherited methods & properties.
Contains example of ArrayList<T> if not defined in implementation.
For ten additional points (+10) students may demonstrate working knowledge of the protected access modifier. For more information on key word protected please review the following link: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/protected-keyword-in-java-with-examples/

As always, correct style and good documentation (comments) are required for full points.

LAB 4 PART 2 & 3 DUE DATE: Sunday, January 12th @ 11.59pm
announcement.textHtml:
Lab 4: 👩‍🎤📈 OOPs! I Did It Again 👩‍🎤📈

In this lab exercise students will explore Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts in Java by creating their own inheritance structure.

Key Concepts
  • Inheritance (extends, implements)
  • Polymorphism (instanceof)
  • Key word abstract
  • Key word super
  • Access modifiers (public, private), setter() / getter() design pattern.
  • ArrayList<T>
This lab is broken down into three parts -- students must complete all three sections to receive full credit. Students may work in groups, but all work will be submitted and graded individually. Students may begin the lab by forking & cloning the following repository: https://github.com/bmazey/st-saviour-oop-java

Part 1: Unified Model Language (UML) Diagram (10 points)
Before writing code, students must first create a UML diagram which describes the relationship between their intended classes. The designed structure must contain at least four (4) classes: one abstract grandparent class, one parent class, and two children classes. The structure must also define at least one interface and a class which implements the interface. The UML diagram may be submitted digitally or drawn on paper.

More information on UML class diagrams can be found here: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/unified-modeling-language-uml-class-diagrams/

LAB 4 PART 1 DUE DATE: Friday, December 13th 2024 (submitted in class, or on Google Classroom)

Part 2: Java Implementation (60 points)
After receiving approval on the diagram submitted in Part 1 students may begin the implementation of the designed structure. The structure must address the following criteria for full credit (10 points each):
  • Contains at least four (4) classes, with at least one class being abstract.
  • Demonstrates working knowledge of key word extends.
  • Contains at least one (1) interface, and a class which implements the interface.
  • Demonstrates working knowledge of key word super.
  • Demonstrates knowledge of access modifiers (public, private) using setter() / getter() methods.
  • May or may not contain an example of ArrayList<T>.
Part 3: Tests & Validation (30 points)
Your lab submission should include tests which demonstrate polymorphic types and a functional inheritance hierarchy. The tests must address the following criteria for full credit (10 points each):
  • Asserts polymorphic types using instanceof operator.
  • Confirms presence of inherited methods & properties.
  • Contains example of ArrayList<T> if not defined in implementation.
For ten additional points (+10) students may demonstrate working knowledge of the protected access modifier. For more information on key word protected please review the following link: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/protected-keyword-in-java-with-examples/

As always, correct style and good documentation (comments) are required for full points.

LAB 4 PART 2 & 3 DUE DATE: Sunday, January 12th @ 11.59pm

driveFile.title: Copy of November Practice Solutions, Java.pdf

announcement.text:
November Quiz Practice Problems

Solutions are attached -- DO NOT view solutions before attempting the problems!

Question 1
Create a truth table for the following boolean expression: !(a or b)

Question 2
Write a public static method coinFlip() which accepts no arguments and returns a String. The method should simulate a 50 / 50 coin flip and return 'Heads' or 'Tails'. 

Question 3
Write a public static method boxCars() which accepts no arguments and returns a boolean. The function should roll two six-sided die and return true iff (if and only if) both die land on the number 6.

Question 4
Design a Cake class. Your Cake class should include the following public data properties: flavor, layers, and isBirthday. The flavor property should represent the flavor of cake. The layers property should represent how many layers the cake has. The isBirthday property should represent if the Cake is a birthday cake or not.

Your Cake class should implement a default constructor which creates a vanilla cake with three layers for a birthday. Your Cake class should also include a constructor which allows the user to customize all values.

Your Cake class should include a public method eat() which returns a String message. The message should include the flavor and layers. If the Cake is a birthday cake, the message should also include 'Happy birthday!' 

---

Good luck,

Mr. Mazey

Solutions are attached -- DO NOT view solutions before attempting the problems!

Question 1

Question 2
Write a public static method coinFlip() which accepts no arguments and returns a String. The method should simulate a 50 / 50 coin flip and return 'Heads' or 'Tails'.

Question 3
Write a public static method boxCars() which accepts no arguments and returns a boolean. The function should roll two six-sided die and return true iff (if and only if) both die land on the number 6.

Question 4
Design a Cake class. Your Cake class should include the following public data properties: flavor, layers, and isBirthday. The flavor property should represent the flavor of cake. The layers property should represent how many layers the cake has. The isBirthday property should represent if the Cake is a birthday cake or not.

Your Cake class should implement a default constructor which creates a vanilla cake with three layers for a birthday. Your Cake class should also include a constructor which allows the user to customize all values.

Your Cake class should include a public method eat() which returns a String message. The message should include the flavor and layers. If the Cake is a birthday cake, the message should also include 'Happy birthday!'

---

Good luck,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
Quiz Topics & Lab 3 Extension

The following topics will be covered on the November quiz which will take place on Tuesday, November 26th.
De Morgan's Laws
Random Number Generation, Math.random()
Writing Methods
OOP Concepts (classes vs. instances, constructor methods, data properties)
The quiz emphasizes free response questions which task you to write methods and design a class in Java. I strongly encourage you to practice writing methods and classes on paper to prepare for the quiz.

Additionally, the due date for Lab 3 has been extended to Wednesday, November 27th at 11.59pm. Remember to have your code pushed to GitHub and submit a link to your repository alongside a short, 30-second video demonstrating your game here on Google Classroom. You may use the screen recording feature of the Chromebook to accomplish this task (see the link below).

Best of luck,

Mr. Mazey
announcement.textHtml:
Quiz Topics & Lab 3 Extension

The following topics will be covered on the November quiz which will take place on Tuesday, November 26th.
  • De Morgan's Laws
  • Random Number Generation, Math.random()
  • Writing Methods
  • OOP Concepts (classes vs. instances, constructor methods, data properties)
The quiz emphasizes free response questions which task you to write methods and design a class in Java. I strongly encourage you to practice writing methods and classes on paper to prepare for the quiz.

Additionally, the due date for Lab 3 has been extended to Wednesday, November 27th at 11.59pm. Remember to have your code pushed to GitHub and submit a link to your repository alongside a short, 30-second video demonstrating your game here on Google Classroom. You may use the screen recording feature of the Chromebook to accomplish this task (see the link below).

Best of luck,

Mr. Mazey

link.title: Image Processing in Java - Read and Write - GeeksforGeeks

announcement.text:
LAB 3: 🗡️🐍 BLUDGEONS & FLAGONS 💀🔥

In this lab students are tasked to build a simple text-based RPG in the spirit of Dungeons & Dragons.

Key Concepts
Object-Oriented Programming (classes & instances)
Methods
Random Number Generators
Students may begin the lab by forking and cloning the following GitHub repository in VSCode: https://github.com/bmazey/st-saviour-dnd-java-fall-24

Grading Criteria
Create a character by accepting user input for name and role (javautil Scanner). When generated, the character should have stats randomly assigned from a default stat array. The default stats are strength, dexterity, constitution, charisma, intelligence, and wisdom. The default stat array is [15, 14, 13, 12, 10, 8]. The character class should have a method which pretty prints the stat sheet at the beginning of the game. (30 points)
The class which contains the main method should also contain a generateMonster() method which accepts no arguments and returns an integer which represents the roll required to beat said monster. The method should randomly generate three different monsters by making print statements. The distribution of random monsters should be approximately 50% / 33.33% / 16.66% with the lesser likely monsters requiring higher rolls to beat. (25 points)
The player character class should contain a roll() method which accepts a buff as a String and simulates a 20-sided die (d20) roll. Before rolling against the monster, the user is prompted to add either the advantage or guidance buff. The user input is captured and provided to the player roll. The advantage buff rolls two d20s, draws both die results, and returns the higher of the two. The guidance buff adds an additional four-sided die (d4) to a d20 roll, draws both, and returns the result. (25 points)
The game should require at least three successful monster encounters for the player to succeed the campaign. If the player fails a roll at any point the game is over and a GAME OVER message is displayed; similarly, a winning message is displayed after a successful campaign. (15 points)
If the player rolls a 20 at any point the game displays CRITICAL SUCCESS. If the player rolls a 1 at any point the game displays CRITICAL FAILURE. You may ignore any corner-cases involving the guidance buff. (5 points)
Please see the short video attached for a demonstration of a working sample game.

Students may implement any of the following features for a +10 bonus:
Keep It Classy -- The game only allows the player to select from a predefined list of playable roles.
Take Initiative -- The game performs an extra roll before combat to determine if the player or if the monster goes first and prints the result. The monster rolls a d20 while player rolls a d20 + (dexterity / 2). 
Level Up -- The player character level increases by 1 every time the player defeats a monster successfully. When the player levels up two additional stat points are randomly assigned and a message is printed to inform the player.
Students are expected to submit their labs by posting a link to their GitHub repository and a short demonstration video similar to the provided example video. 

You are the Dungeon Master! Consider using the links in this post when adding flair to your Bludgeons & Flagons game.

LAB DUE DATE: Friday, November 22nd @ 11.59pm EDT

announcement.text:
October Quiz Topics

The following topics are fair game for the October quiz which will take place this coming Tuesday, October 29th.
Primitive arrays
Loops (for, while, do-while)
Modulo
It is imperative that you fully understand the difference between an index variable and using an index variable to access content within an array (ex: i vs. numbers[i]). You should also be comfortable with problems that task you to 'resize' arrays using counting strategies. Topics such as conditional statements and other subjects which appeared on the September quiz may also reappear.

The quiz will consist of 10 questions each worth 5 points for a total of 50 points. There will be two free response questions which task you to write Java.

Best of luck,

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
LAB 2: 😱 FEAR FACTOR 🎃

In this lab students are tasked to implement functions which manipulate arrays using loops in Java. Students are also tasked to implement a Fibonacci sequence recursively and/or dynamically.

Key Concepts
Iteration (for, while, do while loops)
Arrays
Recursion
Students are expected to submit their work in the form of a PR on GitHub. Recall that all PRs should be opened from a student lab branch against develop, not main! See my previous post for more information on the course repository.

Grading Criteria
Tests & Correctness (70 points)
Documentation (15 points)
Style (10 points)
PR (5 points)
Students may complete the binomial coefficient challenge AND associated tests for +10 bonus points. Please see the associated link for more information on how to compute the binomial coefficient. 

DUE DATE: Friday, October 25th @ 11.59pm EST

DUE DATE: Friday, October 25th @ 11.59pm EST

announcement.text:
Iteration Review Problems

Hi all,

I am out sick today; I intend to be back in class tomorrow. Please use our time today to answer the following questions -- we will review the solutions tomorrow. I encourage you to hand write them first, and then test the soluitions in VSCode rather than writing them directly in VSCode.
Write two, separate loops which each print every multiple of 5 from 0 - 100 (inclusive). Only one of your loops should leverage modulo.
Write a loop which prints the numbers 0 - 9 (inclusive) ten separate times. Your loop should indicate when one 0 - 9 iteration ends and the next begins.

Reconsider the palindrome problem from Lab 1 -- are you able to solve this problem using a standard for loop?


Good luck!

Mr. Mazey
announcement.textHtml:
Iteration Review Problems

Hi all,

I am out sick today; I intend to be back in class tomorrow. Please use our time today to answer the following questions -- we will review the solutions tomorrow. I encourage you to hand write them first, and then test the soluitions in VSCode rather than writing them directly in VSCode.
  • Write two, separate loops which each print every multiple of 5 from 0 - 100 (inclusive). Only one of your loops should leverage modulo.
  • Write a loop which prints the numbers 0 - 9 (inclusive) ten separate times. Your loop should indicate when one 0 - 9 iteration ends and the next begins.

  • Reconsider the palindrome problem from Lab 1 -- are you able to solve this problem using a standard for loop?

Good luck!

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
September Quiz Topics

The following topics are fair game for our September quiz which will take place (ironically) on Tuesday, October 1st.
Primitive data types (int, double, char, boolean)
Truth tables (AND, OR)
Strings (charAt, length, both substring, & equals methods)
Binary numbers
Conditional statements
Measurements of equality
Error families
The quiz will be physical paper format. You will have the entire class period to complete the quiz. You will be asked at least one question which involves writing Java.

We will host a review in class on Monday -- please come prepared to take notes and do exercises on the board.

Good luck,

Mr. Mazey

Mr. Mazey

announcement.text:
LAB 1: ACE THE INTERVIEW

In this lab exercise students will be tasked to solve coding challenges commonly presented in professional (junior) software engineering roles.

Key Concepts
Data Types
Conditional Statements
Modulo
Random Integers
Strings
Measurements of Equality
Students must submit their work in the form of a pull request on our course GitHub repository. Please see my previous post for more information on the course repository.

Grading Criteria
Tests & Correctness (70 points)
Style (20 points)
Documentation (10 points)
A palindrome is a word that is spelled correctly in both forward and reverse order. Students may receive 10 additional bonus points for a correct palindrome detector implementation (see course repository for more details).

DUE DATE: Friday, September 27th at 11:59pm

youtubeVideo.title: How to Install Java on a Chromebook

announcement.text:
VSCode Chromebook Setup

Course lab content will be completed with VSCode IDE. If you do not already have a GitHub account, please see the previous post on course repository before continuing.

Start by activating the Linux subsystem in ChromeOS. This can be done by navigating to ...

Settings (the grey cog) > Advanced (the dropdown at the bottom) > Developers > "Turn On"

Use all recommended settings (including the 10Gb disk size) when activating the Linux subsystem.

Next launch the Penguin Terminal. This should become available either in the same Developers menu or accessible as an app on the start menu. It may also launch automatically after enabling Linux.

Run the following commands ... 

sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get dist-upgrade -y

sudo apt install default-jdk

The first command updates the Linux package manager indices, and the second installs Java. Please see the YouTube video linked below if you are having trouble installing Java. Verify java is installed by running the following command:

java -version

Install Git next by executing the following command:

sudo apt install git-all

Verify Git is installed by running the following command (note the double dash in the command):

git --version

Now on to VSCode. Please follow the steps provided in the following link to install VSCode on the Chromebook. DO NOT INSTALL NPM -- you may stop after the "Install VSCode" section, DO NOT continue on to the Javascript & Node.js section.

Install VSCode: https://code.visualstudio.com/blogs/2020/12/03/chromebook-get-started

You are good to go as long as you are able to start VSCode on the Chromebook. You may choose to clone the class repository given the information in the previous post, but we will do this step together in class.

Please feel free to email me with any questions you may have; thank you,

Mr. Mazey
mazey.b@stsaviour.org
